div1.p: THE BALTIMORE NEWS, WEDNESDAY.
CAUSES YELLOW FEVER

THE MOSQUITO RESPONSIBLE FOR
SPREAD OF DISEASE.

Camp Lazear Experiments Seem Con-
clusive On This Point--Infected
Clothing Not Dangerous.

It has been proved definitely that malaria
is inseparably connected with a mosquito.
The insect acts as the intermediate host in
spreading this disease. There is now evi-
dence that yellow fever is also caused in
human beings by the mosquito, but a dif-
ferent species--one which is not often
found in the northern part of this coun-
try. The mosquito known to physicians
and other scientists as the anopheles
causes malaria; that one known as culex
fasciatus causes yellow fever.

“At first thought one might be tempted
to characterize the experiments upon hu-
man beings as unwarrantable,” said a
prominent doctor; “but as everything was
done with the full consent and full knowl-
edge of the nature of the experiment on
the part of the non-immunes who placed
themselves at the disposal of the experi-
menters, and considering the thousands of
human lives which will be saved and re-
lieved from suffering by these experi-
ments, there can remain no honest reason
for complaint on this score. This is espe-
cially so in instances where the doctors
who conducted these experiments experi-
mented upon themselves. These are exam-
ples of an unselfish devotion to the cause
of humanity.”
Assigned To Investigate Fever.

Drs. Jesse W. Lazear, Walter Reed (who
is to lecture before the Medical and Chi-
rurgical Society in Baltimore on Thursday
night), James Carroll and Aristides Agra-
mente, all of the Medical Department of
the United States Army, were directed by
Surgeon General Sternberg to investigate
the cause of yellow fever, and were as-
signed to Cuba. Maj. Gen. Leonard Wood,
M. D., who is Military Governor of the
Island of Cuba, assisted the above Com-
mission in its studies of the cause of yel-
low fever.

To avoid any possible source of infection
to those individuals who were to be ob-
served, a location for an ideal camp was
selected in an open field, about one mile
from Quemados, Cuba. Here an experi-
mental sanitary station was established.
Died By The Experiment.

While unselfishly experimenting for the
cause of the disease as produced by mos-
quitoes, Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, one of the
Commission and a Johns Hopkins man,
died of yellow fever from the mosquito
which was allowed to bite him. Twelve
days after having been bitten he developed
a fatal case of yellow fever. In his honor
the station was then called Camp Lazear.

The personnel of this camp consisted of
two medical officers, one immune and the
other non-immune; one hospital steward,
an immune; nine privates of the Hospital
Corps, one of whom was immune, and an
immune ambulance driver. Hospital tents,
well drained, exposed to sunlight and
properly floored, were provided, placed 20
feet apart and numbered 1 to 7. The camp
was established on November 20 last, and
was strictly quarantined. No one was per-
mitted to leave or enter the camp except
the three immunes and the Commissioners.
Offered Themselves As Subjects.

Privates of the Hospital Corps, United
States Army, offered themselves, volunta-
rily and with full knowledge of the experi-
ments, to be bitten by various species of
mosquitoes which had been allowed to bite
victims of fatal and dangerous cases of
yellow fever at various times.

The temperatures and pulses were tested
every three hours in Camp Lazear, in or-
der that the earliest symptoms could be
noted.

Four hospital aids who were bitten by
the species of mosquito called culex fas-
ciatus, 12 or 14 days after the insects had
bitten yellow-fever patients, developed
cases of yellow fever. The only cases of
yellow fever which appeared were those
bitten by these mosquitoes.

The precision with which the infection
followed the bite of the mosquito fulfills
the requirements of a scientific experi-
ment.

From the above facts alone it was def-
initely proved that this special mosquito
causes yellow fever. But Drs. Reed, Car-
roll and Agramente, in order to leave no
doubt in the minds of the most skeptical,
went further and adduced even more con-
clusive proofs that the mosquito causes
this dreaded disease, and that nothing else
but the mosquito causes it.

The parasite which causes yellow fever,
after it has been taken into the mosquito's
stomach, requires a certain number of
days to elapse before it is able to reinfect
human beings. This period represents the
time necessary for the micro-organism to
pass from the mosquito's stomach to its
salivary glands. This time is 12 days in
summer weather and about 18 days in
cooler weather.

After showing conclusively that yellow
fever is conveyed by the culex fasciatus,
they proved that this disease cannot be
acquired in any other manner except (like
malaria, which is also caused by the
mosquito bite) by the injection of blood
taken from the yellow-fever patients.
Four of the doctors were subjected to
this method and three of them had yel-
low fever. These experiments were made
by taking two cubic centimeters of blood
from the veins in the forearm with a
sterilized hypodermic syringe from the
yellow-fever patient and inoculating the
non-immune doctor with his full knowl-
edge and consent.

The origin of epidemics of yellow fever
has been frequently attributed to the un-
packing of trunks and boxes that con-
tained supposedly infected clothing, and
thorough disinfection of all clothing and
bedding from yellow-fever ports are re-
quired by all countries, both at the ports
of departure and of arrival. The mere fact
that the individual has resided even a few
days in an infected district has been suffi-
cient to subject his baggage to rigid dis-
infection by the sanitary authorities.
Tested Infection From Clothing.

Drs. Reed, Carroll and Agramente, in
order to find out whether clothing and
bedding which had been contaminated by
the yellow-fever patients could convey
this awful disease, tested by actual ex-
periments upon themselves and other
non-immune human beings this long-held
theory. A small frame house called the
“Infected Clothing and Bedding Building”
was erected at Camp Lazear. It was
tightly ceiled within with tongue and
grooved boards and well battened out-
side. It was provided with two small win-
dows. All openings faced the south in
order to prevent any circulation of air
currents within the house. Permanent
small meshed wire screens closed the
windows and sliding glass sashes and
heavy wooden shutters outside to pre-
vent the entrance of sunlight. The disin-
fecting qualities of sunlight could not
thus be exerted.

Entrance into this house was also ef-
fected from the south through a small
vestibule. A solid door outside and a
wire screen in the middle protected it;
mosquitoes were thus effectually excluded.
During the day and until after sunset
this house was kept securely closed.

Three large boxes filled with sheets,
pillow-slips and blankets, contaminated
by contact with yellow fever patients and
their discharges were placed inside. Many
of these articles were soiled with black
vomit.
Slept In Infected Beds.

One doctor and two of the hospital
corps, all non-immunes, young Amer-
icans, entered this building and deliber-
ately unpacked these boxes. They handled
and shook each article vigorously in order
to disseminate all of the yellow fever
agents about the building. They used
the soiled pillows, sheets, blankets, etc.,
to prepare the beds in which they slept,
and all other articles were hung around
the room.

This room was thus occupied each night
by these three non-immunes for 20 days.
From time to time fresh articles from
yellow fever patients were sent inside.
Their odor was sometimes so offensive
that they had at times to come out in
order to breathe freely.
Came Out In Perfect Health.

When these three were finally given
their liberty they were in perfect health
and remained so, in spite of their un-
wholesome surroundings. Two new non-
immunes entered this house for 20 days
with equal success, and this experiment
was repeated a third time, under even
more disagreeable conditions.

Therefore Drs. Reed, Carroll and Agra-
mente conclude that this disease cannot
be transmitted through the agency of
wearing apparel, or merchandise of any
kind, bedding or anything inanimate.

To discover exactly how a house be-
comes infected with yellow fever these
famous investigators went further. They
erected a second house like the Building
No. 1, and to be known as Building No. 2.
In this they placed the doors and windows
upon opposite sides, in order to have thor-
ough ventilation. Everything which en-
tered No. 2 was carefully disinfected.
The Mosquitoes Did It.

Fifteen mosquitoes -- culex fasciatus --
which had just bitten severe cases of yel-
low fever, were set free in the large room
of this building. A non-immune American
entered the room where the mosquitoes
had been freed and remained only 30 min-
utes. During this time he was bitten about
the face and hands by several insects. The
following day he again entered and was
again bitten. Three days later he devel-
oped a severe case of yellow fever. There
was no other source for his infection be-
cause he had been strictly quarantined in
Camp Lazear for thirty-odd days prior to
his exposure in the mosquito building.
Dr. Lazear The Only Victim.

Now, what is especially important every
one of those who was experimented upon
in the above experiments and developed
yellow fever recovered, owing to the early
diagnosis and new methods employed in
treating the disease. From the above ex-
periments upon these few devoted and
self-sacrificing doctors and nurses, Dr.
Jesse W. Lazear, the first one bitten, was
the only one who succumbed to the dis-
ease. His death saved all of the others.
Conclusions Reached.

Doctors Reed, Carroll and Agramente
publish the following conclusions in a pre-
liminary report in the Journal of the
American Medical Association:

list.item:
(1.) The mosquito known as culex fas-
ciatus serves as the intermediate host for
the parasite of yellow fever.

(2.) Yellow fever is transmitted to the
non-immune individual by means of the
bite of the mosquito that has previously
fed on the blood of those sick with this
disease.

(3.) An interval of 12 days or more after
contamination appears to be necessary be-
fore the mosquito is capable of conveying
the infection.

(4.) The bite of a mosquito at an earlier
period after contamination does not ap-
pear to confer any immunity against a
subsequent attack.

(5.) Yellow fever can be produced by
subcutaneous injection of blood from a
yellow fever patient taken during the first
and second days.

(6.) An attack of yellow fever produced
by the bite of the mosquito confers im-
munity from the disease.

(7.) The period of development of the dis-
ease after the mosquito bite varies from
two to six days.

(8.) Yellow fever is not conveyed by the
discharges of the patient.

(9.) A house is only infected with yellow
fever when contaminated mosquitoes are
present within its walls.

(10.) Yellow fever can be controlled by
destruction of mosquitoes and protection
of the sick from being bitten.
